entry.title: Exploring the electric field around a loop of static charge: Rectangles, stadiums, ellipses, and knots
entry.summary:
Author(s): Max Lipton, Alex Townsend, and Steven H. Strogatz The electrostatic equilibrium points and equipotential surfaces around uniformly charged loops in the plane and knots in three dimensions is studied. Findings include symmetry-breaking bifurcations as well as topological transitions as the shape of the charge distribution or the level of the potential are varied.
[Phys. Rev. Research 4, 033249] Published Fri Sep 30, 2022

author.name: Max Lipton, Alex Townsend, and Steven H. Strogatz

entry.title: Probing antiferromagnetic coupling in magnetic insulator/metal heterostructures
entry.summary:
Author(s): Patrick Quarterman, Yabin Fan, Zhijie Chen, Christopher J. Jensen, Rajesh V. Chopdekar, Dustin A. Gilbert, Megan E. Holtz, Mark D. Stiles, Julie A. Borchers, Kai Liu, Luqiao Liu, and Alexander J. Grutter The recent emergence of antiparallel interface coupling in hybrid ferromagnet metal/ferromagnetic insulator bilayers based on Y3Fe5O12 and NiFe raises questions about magnetic exchange coupling at this technologically important interface. A systematic study of heterostructures incorporating alternative ferromagnetic metals and a variety of substrates reveals that the antiparallel magnetic interaction is unique to heterostructures grown on amorphous SiO2, while multilayers on Gd3Ga5O12 or Gd3Ga5O12/Pt exhibit the traditional parallel exchange. X-ray diffraction implicates changes in the crystal order and orientation, which in a ferrimagnet such as Y3Fe5O12 may expose the minority spin lattice at the reconstructed interface for films on SiO2.
[Phys. Rev. Materials 6, 094418] Published Fri Sep 30, 2022

author.name: Patrick Quarterman, Yabin Fan, Zhijie Chen, Christopher J. Jensen, Rajesh V. Chopdekar, Dustin A. Gilbert, Megan E. Holtz, Mark D. Stiles, Julie A. Borchers, Kai Liu, Luqiao Liu, and Alexander J. Grutter

entry.title: Aerodynamic explanation of flight speed limits in hawkmoth-like flapping-wing insects
entry.summary:
Author(s): Seth Lionetti, Tyson L. Hedrick, and Chengyu Li It has long been unknown why the hawkmoth’s maximum forward flying speed is much lower than the theoretical prediction based on its body mass. Our computational fluid dynamics study revealed that as a hawkmoth’s flight speed increases, its wings inevitably generate a significant amount of negative lift during the upstroke, which renders the hawkmoth incapable of sustaining steady forward flight. A similar trend has also been observed for other insects, including fruit flies and bumblebees. However, birds and other flying vertebrates are able to overcome this limitation by flexing their wings during the upstroke.
[Phys. Rev. Fluids 7, 093104] Published Fri Sep 30, 2022

author.name: Seth Lionetti, Tyson L. Hedrick, and Chengyu Li

entry.title: Probing laser-induced spin-current generation in synthetic ferrimagnets using spin waves
entry.summary:
Author(s): Tom Lichtenberg, Youri L. W. van Hees, Maarten Beens, Caspar J. Levels, Reinoud Lavrijsen, Rembert A. Duine, and Bert Koopmans The role of nonlocal spin transport in technologically highly relevant all-optical magnetization switching (AOS) of rare-earth transition metal ferrimagnets is scarcely understood. The authors investigate spin-current generation in layered systems containing Gd and Tb by studying spin-waves that these spin currents excite in an adjacent ferromagnetic layer. They observe a large discrepancy in spin-current generation between Gd and Tb, which provides a possible explanation for the relative difficulty of achieving AOS in systems containing only Tb as the rare-earth material.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 094436] Published Fri Sep 30, 2022

author.name: Tom Lichtenberg, Youri L. W. van Hees, Maarten Beens, Caspar J. Levels, Reinoud Lavrijsen, Rembert A. Duine, and Bert Koopmans

entry.title: Guidelines for Engineering Directional Polariton Launchers
entry.summary:
Author(s): Rafael A. Mayer, Flávio H. Feres, Francisco C.B. Maia, Ingrid D. Barcelos, Alexander S. McLeod, Aleksandr Rodin, and Raul O. Freitas Plasmonic antennas as polariton launchers are crucial for light manipulation down to the nanoscale. However, unlike their well-established radio-frequency counterparts, these nanoantennas lack a roadmap for their purpose-driven design. This study offers a framework based on rf concepts for approaching directional polariton launchers in two-dimensional systems. By offering several guidelines applied to simulations and near-field experiments, the work promises to accelerate the engineering of polariton launchers for tomorrow’s nanophotonic devices.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034089] Published Fri Sep 30, 2022

author.name: Rafael A. Mayer, Flávio H. Feres, Francisco C.B. Maia, Ingrid D. Barcelos, Alexander S. McLeod, Aleksandr Rodin, and Raul O. Freitas

entry.title: First experiment at the Super Heavy Element Factory: High cross section of $^{288}\mathrm{Mc}$ in the $^{243}\mathrm{Am}+^{48}\mathrm{Ca}$ reaction and identification of the new isotope $^{264}\mathrm{Lr}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yu. Ts. Oganessian et al. Initial findings of the Super Heavy Element Factory—an atom smasher in Russia—reveal details about some of the heaviest known elements.
[Phys. Rev. C 106, L031301] Published Thu Sep 29, 2022

author.name: Yu. Ts. Oganessian et al.

entry.title: Zero-point renormalization of the band gap of semiconductors and insulators using the projector augmented wave method
entry.summary:
Author(s): Manuel Engel, Henrique Miranda, Laurent Chaput, Atsushi Togo, Carla Verdi, Martijn Marsman, and Georg Kresse Electron-phonon physics has become an integral part of today’s materials science world. In this work, the authors present ab initio results for the zero-point renormalization of the band gap of various semiconductors and insulators. They use a new implementation of the VASP code that utilizes the sophisticated projector augmented wave method to calculate the electron-phonon perturbation. Two complementary ways of treating the all-electron information are discussed in this context.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 094316] Published Thu Sep 29, 2022

author.name: Manuel Engel, Henrique Miranda, Laurent Chaput, Atsushi Togo, Carla Verdi, Martijn Marsman, and Georg Kresse

entry.title: Low-Noise and Linear Nonmagnetic Circulator by a Temporal Nonreciprocal Phase Shifter
entry.summary:
Author(s): Sajjad Taravati and George V. Eleftheriades Light may be manipulated not only in space, but also in time. This study uses a nonreciprocal temporal-loop-based phase shifter to construct a low-noise, low-profile, and linear nonmagnetic circulator. In contrast to conventional magnet-based circulators, such a temporal circulator is controllable, compatible with integrated-circuit technology, and suitable for high frequencies. The experimental demonstration at microwave frequencies seems very promising.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034082] Published Thu Sep 29, 2022

author.name: Sajjad Taravati and George V. Eleftheriades

entry.title: Trapped-Hydrogen-Induced Energy Loss in Tin-Based Hybrid Perovskite Solar Cells
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yuhang Liang, Xiangyuan Cui, Feng Li, Catherine Stampfl, Simon P. Ringer, Jun Huang, and Rongkun Zheng Tin halide perovskites present outstanding optoelectronic properties and great application potential, without the toxicity of lead. Here a systematic first-principles investigation reveals that a high-density defect complex, consisting of a tin vacancy plus a hydrogen molecule (VSn–H2), is a highly effective center for nonradiative recombination of electrons and holes in this semiconductor. That would explain the experimentally observed significant nonradiative loss in devices based on formamidinium tin triiodide. Therefore, the passivation of this defect complex is expected to improve the performance of tin-based perovskite solar cells and other optoelectronic devices.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034084] Published Thu Sep 29, 2022

author.name: Yuhang Liang, Xiangyuan Cui, Feng Li, Catherine Stampfl, Simon P. Ringer, Jun Huang, and Rongkun Zheng

entry.title: Driven anti-Bragg subradiant correlations in waveguide quantum electrodynamics
entry.summary:
Author(s): Alexander N. Poddubny It is theoretically predicted that strong electromagnetic driving of an array of two-level atoms, coupled to a waveguide, can make quantum excitations of the array decay faster.
[Phys. Rev. A 106, L031702] Published Thu Sep 29, 2022

author.name: Alexander N. Poddubny

entry.title: Experimental Evidence of Nonlinear Focusing in Standing Water Waves
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yuchen He, Alexey Slunyaev, Nobuhito Mori, and Amin Chabchoub Researchers create the most realistic rogue waves to date, showing dynamics that follow those expected for extreme waves in more idealized systems.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 144502] Published Wed Sep 28, 2022

author.name: Yuchen He, Alexey Slunyaev, Nobuhito Mori, and Amin Chabchoub

entry.title: Thermodynamic metric geometry and the Fisher-Widom line of simple fluids
entry.summary:
Author(s): Peter Mausbach, Robin Fingerhut, and Jadran Vrabec The concept of curvature in Riemannian geometry can be used to study equilibrium thermodynamics. In this paper, the authors analyze the Ricci curvature for several simple model fluids and examine the behavior of two boundary lines in the fluids’ phase diagrams.
[Phys. Rev. E 106, 034136] Published Wed Sep 28, 2022

author.name: Peter Mausbach, Robin Fingerhut, and Jadran Vrabec

entry.title: Antipolar transitions in ${\mathrm{GaNb}}_{4}{\mathrm{Se}}_{8}$ and ${\mathrm{GaTa}}_{4}{\mathrm{Se}}_{8}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): M. Winkler, L. Prodan, V. Tsurkan, P. Lunkenheimer, and I. Kézsmárki Applying dielectric spectroscopy and other techniques, the authors find antipolar ordering at the structural and magnetic transitions of the lacunar spinels GaNb4Se8 and GaTa4Se8, materials with substantial spin-orbit coupling. It arises from polar distortions of the moleculelike Nb4Se4 and Ta4Se4 clusters, typical for the crystalline lattice of lacunar spinels. Moreover, aside from dipolar relaxations and weak ferroelectric ordering, charge transport governed by in-gap impurity states is found at low temperatures, as previously suggested to explain the resistive switching in these compounds.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 115146] Published Wed Sep 28, 2022

author.name: M. Winkler, L. Prodan, V. Tsurkan, P. Lunkenheimer, and I. Kézsmárki

entry.title: Order fractionalization in a Kitaev-Kondo model
entry.summary:
Author(s): Alexei M. Tsvelik and Piers Coleman “Order fractionalization” results when a Yao-Lee spin liquid on a honeycomb lattice is exchange coupled to a conduction sea to form a Kondo lattice. Binding between the electrons and the Majorana excitations of the spin liquid gives rise to a condensate of charge-e S=½ spinor bosons. The tunneling of electrons through the spin liquid takes place over arbitrarily large distances, giving rise to a gapless cone of neutral Majorana excitations.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 125144] Published Wed Sep 28, 2022

author.name: Alexei M. Tsvelik and Piers Coleman

entry.title: Emergence of Fermi’s Golden Rule
entry.summary:
Author(s): Tobias Micklitz, Alan Morningstar, Alexander Altland, and David A. Huse Researchers have calculated the likelihood that a quantum state will decay when its evolution is inhibited by a lack of availability of final states.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 140402] Published Tue Sep 27, 2022

author.name: Tobias Micklitz, Alan Morningstar, Alexander Altland, and David A. Huse

entry.title: From inertial to viscous slumping: Numerical and experimental insights of a transient intermediate regime
entry.summary:
Author(s): Alexis Bougouin and Laurent Lacaze The transition from a purely inertial to a purely viscous liquid slumping induced by a dam-break flow over a horizontal surface is highlighted and characterized as a specific adaptive regime, during which the viscous regime progressively invades the entire current.
[Phys. Rev. Fluids 7, 094803] Published Tue Sep 27, 2022

author.name: Alexis Bougouin and Laurent Lacaze

entry.title: Experimental determination of the propulsion matrix of the body of helical Magnetospirillum magneticum cells
entry.summary:
Author(s): Liu Yu (虞柳), Lucas Le Nagard, Solomon Barkley, Lauren Smith, and Cécile Fradin How microorganisms swim depends on the friction they experience under both translational and rotational motion. An experimental study of helical bacteria shows how various friction coefficients depend on the shape of the bacteria, and shows that cell body rotation could significantly contribute to cellular propulsion.
[Phys. Rev. E 106, 034407] Published Tue Sep 27, 2022

author.name: Liu Yu (虞柳), Lucas Le Nagard, Solomon Barkley, Lauren Smith, and Cécile Fradin

entry.title: Transverse Electron-Beam Shaping with Light
entry.summary:
Author(s): Marius Constantin Chirita Mihaila, Philipp Weber, Matthias Schneller, Lucas Grandits, Stefan Nimmrichter, and Thomas Juffmann A new method that uses laser light to both generate and shape electron beams could improve the resolution of electron microscopy.
[Phys. Rev. X 12, 031043] Published Mon Sep 26, 2022

author.name: Marius Constantin Chirita Mihaila, Philipp Weber, Matthias Schneller, Lucas Grandits, Stefan Nimmrichter, and Thomas Juffmann

entry.title: Quantum Critical Behavior of Entanglement in Lattice Bosons with Cavity-Mediated Long-Range Interactions
entry.summary:
Author(s): Shraddha Sharma, Simon B. Jäger, Rebecca Kraus, Tommaso Roscilde, and Giovanna Morigi Scaling of entanglement entropy can signal the different phase transitions in a two-dimensional quantum many-body system with long-range interactions.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 143001] Published Mon Sep 26, 2022

author.name: Shraddha Sharma, Simon B. Jäger, Rebecca Kraus, Tommaso Roscilde, and Giovanna Morigi

entry.title: Ultrafast carrier and lattice dynamics in the Dirac semimetal ${\mathrm{NiTe}}_{2}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): L. Cheng, F. C. Fei, H. Hu, Y. M. Dai, F. Q. Song, and J. Qi The nonequilibrium fermionic quasiparticle responding to bosonic modes is critical to understand the electromagnetic response of different materials. Using ultrafast optical spectroscopy, this work reveals that sudden variation in the Fermi surface topology induces exotic carrier and phonon dynamics via electron-phonon interaction in the type-II Dirac semimetal NiTe2. This provides the feasibility to manipulate the nonequilibrium carrier and lattice responses in a variety of materials with similar electronic structure, and benefits the development of future ultrafast optoelectronic devices.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 104308] Published Mon Sep 26, 2022

author.name: L. Cheng, F. C. Fei, H. Hu, Y. M. Dai, F. Q. Song, and J. Qi

entry.title: Optimal Steering of Matrix Product States and Quantum Many-Body Scars
entry.summary:
Author(s): Marko Ljubotina, Barbara Roos, Dmitry A. Abanin, and Maksym Serbyn An approach to control quantum many-body systems based on matrix product states is introduced and applied to a system with quantum many-body scars, allowing one to improve the stability of revivals and to utilize scarred dynamics to manipulate entanglement with high fidelity.
[PRX Quantum 3, 030343] Published Fri Sep 23, 2022

author.name: Marko Ljubotina, Barbara Roos, Dmitry A. Abanin, and Maksym Serbyn

entry.title: Impact of Negative Geostrophic Wind Shear on Wind Farm Performance
entry.summary:
Author(s): Anja Stieren, Jens H. Kasper, Srinidhi N. Gadde, and Richard J.A.M. Stevens Simulations reveal how negative shear baroclinicity affects atmospheric turbulence and impacts wind farm power production.
[PRX Energy 1, 023007] Published Fri Sep 23, 2022

author.name: Anja Stieren, Jens H. Kasper, Srinidhi N. Gadde, and Richard J.A.M. Stevens

entry.title: Changing Flows Balance Nutrient Absorption and Bacterial Growth along the Gut
entry.summary:
Author(s): Agnese Codutti, Jonas Cremer, and Karen Alim Fluid dynamics simulations suggest that the varying flow speed inside the small intestine maximizes nutrient absorption while minimizing excess bacteria.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 138101] Published Fri Sep 23, 2022

author.name: Agnese Codutti, Jonas Cremer, and Karen Alim

entry.title: Effect of ambient gas on cavity formation for sphere impacts on liquids
entry.summary:
Author(s): Hollis Williams, James Sprittles, Juan C. Padrino, and Petr Denissenko The influence of the surrounding gas on cavity formation behind a sphere impacting a body of liquid is studied. Contrary to the classical picture, it is found that, in a range of parameters, cavity formation can be suppressed by lowering the density of the ambient gas. This is attributed to the gas slowing sealing of the thin crown sheet behind the sphere.
[Phys. Rev. Fluids 7, 094003] Published Fri Sep 23, 2022

author.name: Hollis Williams, James Sprittles, Juan C. Padrino, and Petr Denissenko

entry.title: Spin orbit torque driven magnetization reversal in CoFeTaB/Pt probed by resonant x-ray reflectivity
entry.summary:
Author(s): D. M. Burn, R. Fan, O. Inyang, M. Tokaç, L. Bouchenoire, A. T. Hindmarch, and P. Steadman When electrical current flows through a heavy metal layer adjacent to a ferromagnetic layer, a spin-orbit torque is exerted on the magnetic spins within the ferromagnetic layer. This link between electronics and magnetic materials is significant for the development of novel technological memory and processing devices in a field known as spintronics. Here, the authors show how advanced synchrotron radiation techniques provide a new, nondestructive, and in situ view of the current-driven layer-dependent magnetization reversal in a spintronic bilayer system.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 094429] Published Fri Sep 23, 2022

author.name: D. M. Burn, R. Fan, O. Inyang, M. Tokaç, L. Bouchenoire, A. T. Hindmarch, and P. Steadman

entry.title: Phonon softening in $\mathrm{Lu}{({\mathrm{Pt}}_{1−x}{\mathrm{Pd}}_{x})}_{2}\mathrm{In}$ close to a zero-temperature structural instability
entry.summary:
Author(s): T. Gruner, S. Lucas, C. Geibel, K. Kaneko, S. Tsutsui, K. Schmalzl, and O. Stockert The structural transition in Lu(Pt1−xPdx)2In attracts special interest since it can be tuned to zero temperature with the appearance of a superconducting dome around structural quantum criticality. The authors combined inelastic neutron and x-ray scattering measurements to study this structural transition. They determined the low-energy phonon dispersions and detected the relevant phonon branch becoming soft. While theoretical calculations broadly agree with the measured dispersion, a clear non-mean-field behavior is demonstrated at this phase transition, which might be connected with quantum criticality and the superconducting dome.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 115142] Published Fri Sep 23, 2022

author.name: T. Gruner, S. Lucas, C. Geibel, K. Kaneko, S. Tsutsui, K. Schmalzl, and O. Stockert

entry.title: Entanglement features of random neural network quantum states
entry.summary:
Author(s): Xiao-Qi Sun, Tamra Nebabu, Xizhi Han, Michael O. Flynn, and Xiao-Liang Qi Neural networks offer a novel approach to represent wave functions for solving quantum many-body problems. But what kinds of quantum states are efficiently represented by neural networks? To approach this problem, the authors study here entanglement properties of an ensemble of neural network states represented by random restricted Boltzmann machines. Phases with distinct entanglement features are identified and characterized. In particular, the authors show that these neural network states can look typical in their entanglement profile while still being distinguishable from a typical state by their fractal dimensions.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 115138] Published Thu Sep 22, 2022

author.name: Xiao-Qi Sun, Tamra Nebabu, Xizhi Han, Michael O. Flynn, and Xiao-Liang Qi

entry.title: Uniaxial ferromagnetism in the kagome metal ${\mathrm{TbV}}_{6}{\mathrm{Sn}}_{6}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): Elliott Rosenberg, Jonathan M. DeStefano, Yucheng Guo, Ji Seop Oh, Makoto Hashimoto, Donghui Lu, Robert J. Birgeneau, Yongbin Lee, Liqin Ke, Ming Yi, and Jiun-Haw Chu The RT6X6 family (R=rare earth, T=transition metal) offers an interplay of magnetism with potentially nontrivial topological kagome band structures. Here, the authors present a new member TbV6Sn6, which contains a pure vanadium kagome lattice. Thermodynamic, magnetometric, and transport measurements reveal an Ising ferromagnetism of local Tb 4f moments accompanied by an anomalous Hall effect below 4.1 K. The Tb magnetism displays a strikingly large uniaxial anisotropy, which the authors argue originates from 4f crystalline electric field effects in a hexagonal symmetry environment.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 115139] Published Thu Sep 22, 2022

author.name: Elliott Rosenberg, Jonathan M. DeStefano, Yucheng Guo, Ji Seop Oh, Makoto Hashimoto, Donghui Lu, Robert J. Birgeneau, Yongbin Lee, Liqin Ke, Ming Yi, and Jiun-Haw Chu

entry.title: Weakly Flux-Tunable Superconducting Qubit
entry.summary:
Author(s): José M. Chávez-Garcia, Firat Solgun, Jared B. Hertzberg, Oblesh Jinka, Markus Brink, and Baleegh Abdo Superconducting qubits are building blocks for quantum processors, but they suffer from frequency collisions, which hinder the construction of large qubit lattices. This study introduces weakly tunable qubits, whose frequency can be tuned over a small range via external magnetic flux. Through theoretical derivation and experimental demonstration, the authors show that these transmonlike qubits—without losing the desired key properties—can be used to avoid frequency collisions in large qubit systems while minimizing the sensitivity to flux noise. They can also be applied to operate flux-tuned qubit gates.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034057] Published Thu Sep 22, 2022

author.name: José M. Chávez-Garcia, Firat Solgun, Jared B. Hertzberg, Oblesh Jinka, Markus Brink, and Baleegh Abdo

entry.title: Low-Frequency Quantum Sensing
entry.summary:
Author(s): E.D. Herbschleb, I. Ohki, K. Morita, Y. Yoshii, H. Kato, T. Makino, S. Yamasaki, and N. Mizuochi Quantum sensing of low-frequency fields is important for nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) due to its rich structure and narrow line widths, both at low fields focusing on J couplings and at high fields for down-converted frequencies from conventional NMR. However, the most sensitive and coherent quantum sensing methods work at dc and high-frequency fields only. This study utilizes a quantum oscilloscope approach to bridge this gap. The resulting algorithm has a frequency-independent sensitivity and is able to work in the zero-field region. This approach would have an impact on designing low-frequency measurements where the high sensitivities of quantum sensors are an indispensable treat.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034058] Published Thu Sep 22, 2022

author.name: E.D. Herbschleb, I. Ohki, K. Morita, Y. Yoshii, H. Kato, T. Makino, S. Yamasaki, and N. Mizuochi

entry.title: Bayesian Information Engine that Optimally Exploits Noisy Measurements
entry.summary:
Author(s): Tushar K. Saha, Joseph N. E. Lucero, Jannik Ehrich, David A. Sivak, and John Bechhoefer A “filtering” algorithm allows information engines to perform efficiently even when they are subjected to high noise.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 130601] Published Wed Sep 21, 2022

author.name: Tushar K. Saha, Joseph N. E. Lucero, Jannik Ehrich, David A. Sivak, and John Bechhoefer

entry.title: Covariant density functional theory with localized exchange terms
entry.summary:
Author(s): Qiang Zhao (赵强), Zhengxue Ren (任政学), Pengwei Zhao (赵鹏巍), and Jie Meng (孟杰) The authors derive a new density-dependent point-coupling covariant density functional (PCF-PK1) with exchange terms that are local and can be included in a standard relativistic mean-field calculation. This saves a considerable amount of computing time over relativistic Hartree-Fock calculations with nonlocal potentials. The PCF-PK1 is obtained by fitting nuclear matter and finite nuclei, including the results of ab-initio calculations; it eliminates spurious shell closures at Z=58 and 92; and it accurately reproduces Gamow-Teller resonances in closed-shell nuclei. This new covariant density functional PCF-PK1 with exchange correlation is expected to provide a unified and consistent description for both nuclear ground states and excited states, in particular for unstable nuclei far from stability.
[Phys. Rev. C 106, 034315] Published Wed Sep 21, 2022

author.name: Qiang Zhao (赵强), Zhengxue Ren (任政学), Pengwei Zhao (赵鹏巍), and Jie Meng (孟杰)

entry.title: Driven Disordered Systems Approach to Biological Evolution in Changing Environments
entry.summary:
Author(s): Suman G. Das, Joachim Krug, and Muhittin Mungan A bacterial genome’s evolution under changing drug concentrations displays effects of memory formation and mimics how disordered solids respond to external forces.
[Phys. Rev. X 12, 031040] Published Tue Sep 20, 2022

author.name: Suman G. Das, Joachim Krug, and Muhittin Mungan

entry.title: Geometry Adaptation of Protrusion and Polarity Dynamics in Confined Cell Migration
entry.summary:
Author(s): David B. Brückner, Matthew Schmitt, Alexandra Fink, Georg Ladurner, Johannes Flommersfeld, Nicolas Arlt, Edouard Hannezo, Joachim O. Rädler, and Chase P. Broedersz Experiments demonstrate that biological cells actively change shape to respond to their surroundings when moving in confined regions.
[Phys. Rev. X 12, 031041] Published Tue Sep 20, 2022

author.name: David B. Brückner, Matthew Schmitt, Alexandra Fink, Georg Ladurner, Johannes Flommersfeld, Nicolas Arlt, Edouard Hannezo, Joachim O. Rädler, and Chase P. Broedersz

entry.title: In-medium $\mathrm{Λ}$ isospin impurity from charge symmetry breaking in the ${}_{\mathrm{Λ}}^{4}\mathrm{H}\text{−}{}_{\mathrm{Λ}}^{4}\mathrm{He}$ mirror hypernuclei
entry.summary:
Author(s): M. Schäfer, N. Barnea, and A. Gal Charge-symmetry breaking, or CSB, is a fundamental concept in nuclear physics. Adding a Λ hyperon, a sibling of the nucleon with a strange quark, to light nuclei promises new insights as its isospin impurity must impact CSB in mirror hypernuclei, where the only good data available are for A=4. The authors use an ansatz that relates the charge-symmetry-breaking ΛN interaction to the ΛN↔ΣN strong-interaction coupling via the small isospin-one admixture the Λ obtains from the Σ0, as both are members of an SU(3) baryon octet and have an u-d-s quark structure. Once the large CSB observed in mirror hypernuclei Λ4H and Λ4He is reproduced, the deduced isospin-one admixture of the Λ when inside these hypernuclei matches that in free space, provided SU(3) symmetry is partially conserved for these baryons. This approach can be tested in heavier hypernuclei when precise data for CSB become available.
[Phys. Rev. C 106, L031001] Published Tue Sep 20, 2022

author.name: M. Schäfer, N. Barnea, and A. Gal

entry.title: Force-Detected Magnetic Resonance Imaging of Influenza Viruses in the Overcoupled Sensor Regime
entry.summary:
Author(s): Marc-Dominik Krass, Nils Prumbaum, Raphael Pachlatko, Urs Grob, Hiroki Takahashi, Yohei Yamauchi, Christian L. Degen, and Alexander Eichler Ultrasensitive nanomechanical sensors are envisioned to enable nanoscale magnetic resonance imaging (nano-MRI) and other scanning force microscopy applications. However, their sensitivity to very small forces makes such sensors susceptible to unwanted tip-surface interactions that cause bending and instability. This study shows how these noncontact interactions affect scanning force measurements. The authors present strategies to overcome the challenges of overcoupling, which lead to the successful demonstration of faithful nano-MRI reconstruction of individual influenza viruses.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034052] Published Tue Sep 20, 2022

author.name: Marc-Dominik Krass, Nils Prumbaum, Raphael Pachlatko, Urs Grob, Hiroki Takahashi, Yohei Yamauchi, Christian L. Degen, and Alexander Eichler

entry.title: Nonuniversality of quantum noise in optical amplifiers operating at exceptional points
entry.summary:
Author(s): L. Simonson, S. K. Ozdemir, A. Eisfeld, A. Metelmann, and R. El-Ganainy The quantum noise in exceptional points-based optical amplifiers does not scale universally with the order of the exceptional point but rather can vary from one implementation to another.
[Phys. Rev. Research 4, 033226] Published Mon Sep 19, 2022

author.name: L. Simonson, S. K. Ozdemir, A. Eisfeld, A. Metelmann, and R. El-Ganainy

entry.title: Wave Packet Dynamics in Synthetic Non-Abelian Gauge Fields
entry.summary:
Author(s): Mehedi Hasan, Chetan Sriram Madasu, Ketan D. Rathod, Chang Chi Kwong, Christian Miniatura, Frédéric Chevy, and David Wilkowski Researchers produce analogues of hard-to-study quantum phenomena in a gas of strontium atoms near absolute zero.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 130402] Published Mon Sep 19, 2022

author.name: Mehedi Hasan, Chetan Sriram Madasu, Ketan D. Rathod, Chang Chi Kwong, Christian Miniatura, Frédéric Chevy, and David Wilkowski

entry.title: Self-Kerr Effect across the Yellow Rydberg Series of Excitons in ${\mathrm{Cu}}_{2}\mathrm{O}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): Corentin Morin, Jérôme Tignon, Juliette Mangeney, Sukhdeep Dhillon, Gerard Czajkowski, Karol Karpiński, Sylwia Zielińska-Raczyńska, David Ziemkiewicz, and Thomas Boulier Researchers have demonstrated that a solid can exhibit an enhanced nonlinear optical phenomenon usually seen only in cold atomic gases.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 137401] Published Mon Sep 19, 2022

author.name: Corentin Morin, Jérôme Tignon, Juliette Mangeney, Sukhdeep Dhillon, Gerard Czajkowski, Karol Karpiński, Sylwia Zielińska-Raczyńska, David Ziemkiewicz, and Thomas Boulier

entry.title: Thermodynamic insights into the intricate magnetic phase diagram of ${\mathrm{EuAl}}_{4}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): William R. Meier, James R. Torres, Raphael P. Hermann, Jiyong Zhao, Barbara Lavina, Brian C. Sales, and Andrew F. May Topological spin textures like skyrmions and merons have been proposed to explain a topological Hall signal observed in magnetically ordered phases of EuAl4. Here, the authors investigate these phases via many complementary thermodynamic measurements of EuAl4 single crystals and discuss the symmetry implications of the results. The study provides a detailed magnetic phase diagram to guide future investigations, which includes three phase boundaries that were not previously identified.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 094421] Published Mon Sep 19, 2022

author.name: William R. Meier, James R. Torres, Raphael P. Hermann, Jiyong Zhao, Barbara Lavina, Brian C. Sales, and Andrew F. May

entry.title: Analytical non-Hermitian description of photonic crystals with arbitrary lateral and transverse symmetry
entry.summary:
Author(s): Xavier Letartre, Serge Mazauric, Sébastien Cueff, Taha Benyattou, Hai Son Nguyen, and Pierre Viktorovitch The authors propose a non-Hermitian Hamiltonian to describe the resonances of photonic crystal slabs formed by coupled high-index contrast gratings. This model can potentially enable the discovery of novel photonic specie through the manipulation of bound states in the continuum and exceptional points. The authors then demonstrate experimentally, as proof-of-concept, the formation of a Dirac point at the merging of three bound states in the continuum.
[Phys. Rev. A 106, 033510] Published Mon Sep 19, 2022

author.name: Xavier Letartre, Serge Mazauric, Sébastien Cueff, Taha Benyattou, Hai Son Nguyen, and Pierre Viktorovitch

entry.title: Physical properties of the layered $f$-electron van der Waals magnet ${\mathrm{Ce}}_{2}{\mathrm{Te}}_{5}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yu Liu (刘育), M. M. Bordelon, A. Weiland, P. F. S. Rosa, S. M. Thomas, J. D. Thompson, F. Ronning, and E. D. Bauer Layered van der Waals (vdW) magnetic materials have attracted widespread attention as new platforms for understanding and controlling magnetism in the two-dimensional limit for spintronic devices. In contrast to 3d-electron vdW magnets, very few f-electron vdW magnets have been studied. Here, the authors report the physical properties of Ce2Te5 single crystals, a layered 4f-electron vdW magnet. Four consecutive (magnetic) phase transitions at ∼ 5.2, 2.1, 0.9, and 0.4 K are observed, suggesting competing antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic exchange interactions. The Hall effect indicates that Ce2Te5 is a multiband system with a relatively high electron mobility, providing opportunities for future device applications.
[Phys. Rev. Materials 6, 094407] Published Fri Sep 16, 2022

author.name: Yu Liu (刘育), M. M. Bordelon, A. Weiland, P. F. S. Rosa, S. M. Thomas, J. D. Thompson, F. Ronning, and E. D. Bauer

entry.title: Observation of Dirac Hierarchy in Three-Dimensional Acoustic Topological Insulators
entry.summary:
Author(s): Linyun Yang, Yin Wang, Yan Meng, Zhenxiao Zhu, Xiang Xi, Bei Yan, Shuxin Lin, Jingming Chen, Bin-jie Shi, Yong Ge, Shou-qi Yuan, Hongsheng Chen, Hong-xiang Sun, Gui-Geng Liu, Yihao Yang, and Zhen Gao Acoustic measurements reveal the full hierarchy of Dirac cones and the corresponding hierarchy of band topology in 3D acoustic crystals.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 125502] Published Fri Sep 16, 2022

author.name: Linyun Yang, Yin Wang, Yan Meng, Zhenxiao Zhu, Xiang Xi, Bei Yan, Shuxin Lin, Jingming Chen, Bin-jie Shi, Yong Ge, Shou-qi Yuan, Hongsheng Chen, Hong-xiang Sun, Gui-Geng Liu, Yihao Yang, and Zhen Gao

entry.title: Energy exchanges in hypersonic flows
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yitong Fan, Weipeng Li, and Sergio Pirozzoli A new framework to quantitatively describe the energy exchange in high-speed turbulent flows is presented. The routes of energy exchange in hypersonic boundary-layer flows are highlighted and quantified, with special attention paid to effects of wall cooling. We expect that the present study can help the development of physics-informed models for compressible turbulence in the class of RANS (Reynolds-averaged Navier-Stokes) and LES (large-eddy-simulation), which currently heavily hinge on variable-density extrapolation of their incompressible counterparts.
[Phys. Rev. Fluids 7, L092601] Published Fri Sep 16, 2022

author.name: Yitong Fan, Weipeng Li, and Sergio Pirozzoli

entry.title: Quantum spin liquid with emergent chiral order in the triangular-lattice Hubbard model
entry.summary:
Author(s): Bin-Bin Chen, Ziyu Chen, Shou-Shu Gong, D. N. Sheng, Wei Li, and Andreas Weichselbaum Despite a plethora of numerical studies, the nature of the quantum spin liquid near the Mott transition in the triangular-lattice Hubbard model remains controversial. Using a careful DMRG analysis on long cylinders up to width 6, the authors identify here a gapped spin liquid with robust chiral long-range correlations. The analysis unveils the need for surprisingly long systems for the spontaneous time-reversal symmetry breaking to occur due to strong open boundary effects. This reconciles previous contradictory results about this quantum spin liquid.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 094420] Published Fri Sep 16, 2022

author.name: Bin-Bin Chen, Ziyu Chen, Shou-Shu Gong, D. N. Sheng, Wei Li, and Andreas Weichselbaum

entry.title: Investigating field-induced magnetic order in Han purple by neutron scattering up to 25.9 T
entry.summary:
Author(s): S. Allenspach, A. Madsen, A. Biffin, M. Bartkowiak, O. Prokhnenko, A. Gazizulina, X. Liu, R. Wahle, S. Gerischer, S. Kempfer, P. Heller, P. Smeibidl, A. Mira, N. Laflorencie, F. Mila, B. Normand, and Ch. Rüegg The material BaCuSi2O6 has a fascinating dual status as an ancient pigment (the original Terracotta Army was colored with Han purple) and as a quasi-two-dimensional quantum magnet at the modern frontier of research into unconventional quantum many-body phenomena. The HFM/EXED facility at the Helmholtz-Zentrum Berlin neutron source allowed the authors to investigate the field-driven quantum phase transition to magnetic order above 23 T by neutron diffraction and spectroscopy. They report their search for fingerprints of the exotic critical behavior predicted to appear in the two-dimensional regime.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 104418] Published Fri Sep 16, 2022

author.name: S. Allenspach, A. Madsen, A. Biffin, M. Bartkowiak, O. Prokhnenko, A. Gazizulina, X. Liu, R. Wahle, S. Gerischer, S. Kempfer, P. Heller, P. Smeibidl, A. Mira, N. Laflorencie, F. Mila, B. Normand, and Ch. Rüegg

entry.title: Dynamics of Reconfigurable Strawlike Elements
entry.summary:
Author(s): Dotan Ilssar, Michael Pukshansky, Yizhar Or, and Amir D. Gat Reconfigurable metamaterials have attracted significant attention due to their cross-disciplinary importance, with applications from deployable space structures to soft robots. These applications might benefit from high-dimensional stable deformations under minimal actuation, which known structures have not demonstrated. The authors present a comprehensive dynamical model and experiments based on pressurized strawlike elements, which are lattices of ungrounded unit cells with high-order multistability. These elements can maintain a myriad of complex stable configurations and exhibit complex dynamical transitions—properties that pave the way toward significant engineering advances.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034041] Published Fri Sep 16, 2022

author.name: Dotan Ilssar, Michael Pukshansky, Yizhar Or, and Amir D. Gat

entry.title: Topological Order, Quantum Codes, and Quantum Computation on Fractal Geometries
entry.summary:
Author(s): Guanyu Zhu, Tomas Jochym-O’Connor, and Arpit Dua A thorough investigation of topological order on fractal geometries and exotic gapped boundaries in 3D is performed, uncovering valuable applications in fault-tolerant quantum computation and mathematical contributions to systolic geometry on fractals.
[PRX Quantum 3, 030338] Published Thu Sep 15, 2022

author.name: Guanyu Zhu, Tomas Jochym-O’Connor, and Arpit Dua

entry.title: Perturbative Quantum Simulation
entry.summary:
Author(s): Jinzhao Sun, Suguru Endo, Huiping Lin, Patrick Hayden, Vlatko Vedral, and Xiao Yuan In this protocol, the main component of the Hamiltonian is simulated on a quantum computer, and classical perturbation theory is used to approximate interactions.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 120505] Published Thu Sep 15, 2022

author.name: Jinzhao Sun, Suguru Endo, Huiping Lin, Patrick Hayden, Vlatko Vedral, and Xiao Yuan

entry.title: Engineering Symmetry-Selective Couplings of a Superconducting Artificial Molecule to Microwave Waveguides
entry.summary:
Author(s): Mohammed Ali Aamir, Claudia Castillo Moreno, Simon Sundelin, Janka Biznárová, Marco Scigliuzzo, Kowshik Erappaji Patel, Amr Osman, D. P. Lozano, Ingrid Strandberg, and Simone Gasparinetti Considering symmetry in waveguide couplings to transmon qubits, quasiselection rules are implemented in superconducting quantum optics.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 123604] Published Thu Sep 15, 2022

author.name: Mohammed Ali Aamir, Claudia Castillo Moreno, Simon Sundelin, Janka Biznárová, Marco Scigliuzzo, Kowshik Erappaji Patel, Amr Osman, D. P. Lozano, Ingrid Strandberg, and Simone Gasparinetti

entry.title: Direct measurement of the aerotactic response in a bacterial suspension
entry.summary:
Author(s): J. Bouvard, C. Douarche, P. Mergaert, H. Auradou, and F. Moisy Many bacteria have the ability to move towards sources of oxygen. The authors’ experiments show that for such motion the response to an oxygen gradient scales as a power law with the oxygen concentration, which is in good agreement with existing models based on the biochemistry of bacterial membrane receptors.
[Phys. Rev. E 106, 034404] Published Thu Sep 15, 2022

author.name: J. Bouvard, C. Douarche, P. Mergaert, H. Auradou, and F. Moisy

entry.title: Magic angles in twisted bilayer graphene near commensuration: Towards a hypermagic regime
entry.summary:
Author(s): Michael G. Scheer, Kaiyuan Gu, and Biao Lian The authors show here that twisted bilayer graphene near an arbitrary commensurate configuration is described by a generalization of the Bistritzer-MacDonald continuum model. They furthermore find magic angles near commensurate configurations that yield flat moiré bands. Additionally, they reveal a hypermagic parameter regime of this model in which numerous moiré bands become flat simultaneously. Some bands in this regime resemble those of kagome lattice or honeycomb lattice px, py tight-binding models, paving the way for future moiré realizations of such systems.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 115418] Published Thu Sep 15, 2022

author.name: Michael G. Scheer, Kaiyuan Gu, and Biao Lian

entry.title: Double-Transmon Coupler: Fast Two-Qubit Gate with No Residual Coupling for Highly Detuned Superconducting Qubits
entry.summary:
Author(s): Hayato Goto Tunable couplers, which turn on and off the interaction between qubits, have emerged as a key means to achieve low error rates in superconducting quantum computers. Conventional devices using one transmon qubit exhibit unwanted residual coupling, though, especially at the high detuning that is desirable for suppressing crosstalk errors. To solve this critical problem, the author proposes a tunable coupler based on two transmons that satisfies the ideal conditions of no residual coupling and fast two-qubit gate operations at high detuning. This double-transmon coupler is expected to become standard for superconducting architectures by eliminating unwanted coupling during idle time.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034038] Published Thu Sep 15, 2022

author.name: Hayato Goto

entry.title: Compact Michelson Interferometers with Subpicometer Sensitivity
entry.summary:
Author(s): Jiri Smetana, Rebecca Walters, Sophie Bauchinger, Amit Singh Ubhi, Sam Cooper, David Hoyland, Richard Abbott, Christoph Baune, Peter Fritchel, Oliver Gerberding, Semjon Köhnke, Haixing Miao, Sebastian Rode, and Denis Martynov A sensor containing thumbnail-sized interferometers might help astronomers detect gravitational waves emitted from certain black hole mergers.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034040] Published Thu Sep 15, 2022

author.name: Jiri Smetana, Rebecca Walters, Sophie Bauchinger, Amit Singh Ubhi, Sam Cooper, David Hoyland, Richard Abbott, Christoph Baune, Peter Fritchel, Oliver Gerberding, Semjon Köhnke, Haixing Miao, Sebastian Rode, and Denis Martynov

entry.title: $MICROSCOPE$ Mission: Final Results of the Test of the Equivalence Principle
entry.summary:
Author(s): Pierre Touboul et al. (MICROSCOPE Collaboration) The MICROSCOPE satellite experiment has tested the equivalence principle with an unprecedented level of precision.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 121102] Published Wed Sep 14, 2022

author.name: Pierre Touboul et al. (MICROSCOPE Collaboration)

entry.title: Two-Dimensional Programmable Tweezer Arrays of Fermions
entry.summary:
Author(s): Zoe Z. Yan, Benjamin M. Spar, Max L. Prichard, Sungjae Chi, Hao-Tian Wei, Eduardo Ibarra-García-Padilla, Kaden R. A. Hazzard, and Waseem S. Bakr An optical tweezer with a stroboscopic twist can trap cold atoms in lattices of all shapes.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 123201] Published Wed Sep 14, 2022

author.name: Zoe Z. Yan, Benjamin M. Spar, Max L. Prichard, Sungjae Chi, Hao-Tian Wei, Eduardo Ibarra-García-Padilla, Kaden R. A. Hazzard, and Waseem S. Bakr

entry.title: Eulerian vs Lagrangian Irreversibility in an Experimental Turbulent Swirling Flow
entry.summary:
Author(s): Adam Cheminet, Damien Geneste, Antoine Barlet, Yasar Ostovan, Tarek Chaabo, Valentina Valori, Paul Debue, Christophe Cuvier, François Daviaud, Jean-Marc Foucaut, Jean-Philippe Laval, Vincent Padilla, Cécile Wiertel-Gasquet, and Bérengère Dubrulle High-resolution Eulerian and Lagrangian measurement in a turbulent facility is used to identify the flow dynamics responsible for the development of the observed time irreversibility.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 124501] Published Wed Sep 14, 2022

author.name: Adam Cheminet, Damien Geneste, Antoine Barlet, Yasar Ostovan, Tarek Chaabo, Valentina Valori, Paul Debue, Christophe Cuvier, François Daviaud, Jean-Marc Foucaut, Jean-Philippe Laval, Vincent Padilla, Cécile Wiertel-Gasquet, and Bérengère Dubrulle

entry.title: Polarons free from many-body self-interaction in density functional theory
entry.summary:
Author(s): Stefano Falletta and Alfredo Pasquarello Semilocal density functional theory generally fails in stabilizing polarons, because of its spurious inclusion of the electron self-interaction. This work addresses the concepts of many-body and one-body self-interaction, which are found to be connected through the dielectric constant within a unified theoretical formulation. The superiority of the many-body self-interaction is demonstrated, resulting in robust polaron formation energies. In this context, an efficient semilocal scheme for polaron localization is developed.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 125119] Published Wed Sep 14, 2022

author.name: Stefano Falletta and Alfredo Pasquarello

entry.title: Nonequilibrium spintronic transport through Kondo impurities
entry.summary:
Author(s): Anand Manaparambil, Andreas Weichselbaum, Jan von Delft, and Ireneusz Weymann The accurate quantitative description of the nonequilibrium transport in interacting nanoscale junctions presents a formidable challenge. Tensor network methods have entered the arena as a highly competitive, versatile, and well-controlled approach. Here, in particular, the authors use a recently developed hybrid renormalization group thermofield quench approach. With this, they obtain reliable predictions for spintronic transport through a Kondo-correlated quantum dot coupled to magnetic leads in far-from-equilibrium conditions. The work focuses on the effects of the induced exchange field. As a key result, they demonstrate that an additional external magnetic field can be utilized to achieve a full Kondo revival in an out-of-equilibrium setting.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 125413] Published Wed Sep 14, 2022

author.name: Anand Manaparambil, Andreas Weichselbaum, Jan von Delft, and Ireneusz Weymann

entry.title: Near-Surface Electrical Characterization of Silicon Electronic Devices Using Focused keV-Range Ions
entry.summary:
Author(s): S.G. Robson, P. Räcke, A.M. Jakob, N. Collins, H.R. Firgau, V. Schmitt, V. Mourik, A. Morello, E. Mayes, D. Spemann, and D.N. Jamieson Already a building block of modern life, silicon is also poised to power the next leap in information technology, in which the quantum mechanical properties of single impurities located just beneath its surface can be used to create vastly more powerful computers. Here a multinational team presents a specialized microscope to better understand the inner workings of such silicon chips, by scanning a finely focused beam of ultralow-energy ions across the surface. The tiny “click” that each ion makes when it hits the chip is detected and mapped, enabling the identification of manufacturing defects; these results can then be fed back to improve the fabrication process.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034037] Published Wed Sep 14, 2022

author.name: S.G. Robson, P. Räcke, A.M. Jakob, N. Collins, H.R. Firgau, V. Schmitt, V. Mourik, A. Morello, E. Mayes, D. Spemann, and D.N. Jamieson

entry.title: Anomalous Electromagnetic Tunneling in Bianisotropic $ϵ\text{−}μ$-Zero Media
entry.summary:
Author(s): Menglin L. N. Chen, Yangang Bi, Hsun-Chi Chan, Zemeng Lin, Shaojie Ma, and Shuang Zhang An unexplored form of tunneling for electromagnetic waves in a medium that exhibits both ϵ−μ−zero and bianisotropy demonstrates opposite behaviors from the electric and magnetic fields.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 123901] Published Tue Sep 13, 2022

author.name: Menglin L. N. Chen, Yangang Bi, Hsun-Chi Chan, Zemeng Lin, Shaojie Ma, and Shuang Zhang

entry.title: From granular collapses to shallow water waves: A predictive model for tsunami generation
entry.summary:
Author(s): Wladimir Sarlin, Cyprien Morize, Alban Sauret, and Philippe Gondret Sudden large-scale geophysical flows such as cliff collapses, rockfalls, or massive landslides are known to be tsunamigenic and constitute a significant hazard for coastal populations and infrastructures. A key challenge is to be able to predict a priori the amplitude of the tsunami wave that would be engendered by a given cliff collapse. In this study, we introduce a comprehensive model of shallow water waves generated by the subaerial collapse of a granular column. The proposed model is able to capture the role of the geometry of the collapse as well as the water depth and is successfully compared to a large dataset of experiments.
[Phys. Rev. Fluids 7, 094801] Published Tue Sep 13, 2022

author.name: Wladimir Sarlin, Cyprien Morize, Alban Sauret, and Philippe Gondret

entry.title: Dynamics of Transmon Ionization
entry.summary:
Author(s): Ross Shillito, Alexandru Petrescu, Joachim Cohen, Jackson Beall, Markus Hauru, Martin Ganahl, Adam G.M. Lewis, Guifre Vidal, and Alexandre Blais Qubit measurement is an essential step in any quantum computation. In circuit quantum electrodynamics, a leading quantum computer architecture, qubit readout is commonly one of the longest and lowest-fidelity processes. The authors numerically explore the dynamics of a driven transmon-resonator system under strong, nearly resonant measurement drives to better understand this issue. They find clear signs of transmon “ionization”, in which the qubit escapes its confining potential under the influence of the drive, and semiclassical methods then reveal the mechanism. This approach can be used to optimize circuit parameters, suppress these spurious effects, and increase readout fidelity.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034031] Published Tue Sep 13, 2022

author.name: Ross Shillito, Alexandru Petrescu, Joachim Cohen, Jackson Beall, Markus Hauru, Martin Ganahl, Adam G.M. Lewis, Guifre Vidal, and Alexandre Blais

entry.title: Geometric link between the Hardy nonlocality condition and the Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt inequality
entry.summary:
Author(s): Johannes Seiler, Thomas Strohm, and Wolfgang P. Schleich The Clauser-Horne-Shimony-Holt inequality and the Hardy condition are both used to detect nonlocality in quantum systems. The authors establish an equivalence between the two by providing a geometrical interpretation of the relevant optimization problem, and find that the golden ratio shows up in their result.
[Phys. Rev. A 106, 032211] Published Tue Sep 13, 2022

author.name: Johannes Seiler, Thomas Strohm, and Wolfgang P. Schleich

entry.title: Nanoscale Magnetism Probed in a Matter-Wave Interferometer
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yaakov Y. Fein, Sebastian Pedalino, Armin Shayeghi, Filip Kiałka, Stefan Gerlich, and Markus Arndt A matter-wave interferometer can probe the magnetism of a broad range of species, from single atoms to very large, weakly magnetic molecules.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 123001] Published Mon Sep 12, 2022

author.name: Yaakov Y. Fein, Sebastian Pedalino, Armin Shayeghi, Filip Kiałka, Stefan Gerlich, and Markus Arndt

entry.title: Free rising skirt bubbles
entry.summary:
Author(s): Dominique Legendre Direct numerical simulation of a rising skirt bubble reveals for the first time two toroidal vortices in the wake (left) as well as vorticity concentrated inside the skirt film (right).
[Phys. Rev. Fluids 7, 093601] Published Mon Sep 12, 2022

author.name: Dominique Legendre

entry.title: Kinetic field theory: Higher-order perturbation theory
entry.summary:
Author(s): Lavinia Heisenberg, Shayan Hemmatyar, and Stefan Zentarra The authors develop a perturbative approach to cosmic structure formation based on Feynman diagrams in close analogy to quantum field theory. This is based on a previously developed path integral formulation for classical systems (Kinetic Field Theory) that includes averaging over probability distributions of initial conditions.
[Phys. Rev. D 106, 063513] Published Mon Sep 12, 2022

author.name: Lavinia Heisenberg, Shayan Hemmatyar, and Stefan Zentarra

entry.title: Analysis of Ringdown Overtones in GW150914
entry.summary:
Author(s): Roberto Cotesta, Gregorio Carullo, Emanuele Berti, and Vitor Cardoso A new analysis questions whether researchers found so-called overtones in the first detected gravitational-wave signal from a black hole merger.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 111102] Published Fri Sep 09, 2022

author.name: Roberto Cotesta, Gregorio Carullo, Emanuele Berti, and Vitor Cardoso

entry.title: Moiré Landau Fans and Magic Zeros
entry.summary:
Author(s): Nisarga Paul, Philip J. D. Crowley, Trithep Devakul, and Liang Fu Universal conditions under which electrons of generic dispersion in a moiré superlattice and magnetic field realize perfectly flat Chern bands have been identified.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 116804] Published Fri Sep 09, 2022

author.name: Nisarga Paul, Philip J. D. Crowley, Trithep Devakul, and Liang Fu

entry.title: Rotation-Time Symmetry Breaking in Frustrated Chiral Nematic Driven by a Pulse-Train Waveform
entry.summary:
Author(s): Vitaly P. Panov, Jiseon Yang, L. K. Migara, Hyun-Jin Yoon, and Jang-Kun Song A liquid crystal can support traveling waves that demonstrate a new ability to control the molecules’ orientations.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 117801] Published Fri Sep 09, 2022

author.name: Vitaly P. Panov, Jiseon Yang, L. K. Migara, Hyun-Jin Yoon, and Jang-Kun Song

entry.title: Waveforms from amplitudes
entry.summary:
Author(s): Andrea Cristofoli, Riccardo Gonzo, David A. Kosower, and Donal O’Connell Waveforms play an important role in the detection of gravitational-wave events from binary mergers. A useful formalism to deal with the two-body problem in gravity is to use quantum scattering amplitudes in a particular expansion and extract classical observables. As an extension to previous work, the authors incorporate massless bosonic particles in the initial states into the formalism and show that in the classical limit they emerge from coherent states due to their nature as superpositions of multiparticle states.
[Phys. Rev. D 106, 056007] Published Fri Sep 09, 2022

author.name: Andrea Cristofoli, Riccardo Gonzo, David A. Kosower, and Donal O’Connell

entry.title: Pairing symmetry of twisted bilayer graphene: A phenomenological synthesis
entry.summary:
Author(s): Ethan Lake, Adarsh S. Patri, and T. Senthil The nature of the superconductor in twisted bilayer graphene has remained a mystery ever since its discovery. Microscopic theoretical approaches are difficult to control, and there has been no single decisive experiment able to completely fix the pairing symmetry. In spite of this, this work shows that by carefully drawing on information from a diverse array of existing experiments – and using some minimal and general input from theory – the nature of the pairing can be almost uniquely determined.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 104506] Published Fri Sep 09, 2022

author.name: Ethan Lake, Adarsh S. Patri, and T. Senthil

entry.title: Search for Dark Matter Annihilation Signals in the H.E.S.S. Inner Galaxy Survey
entry.summary:
Author(s): H. Abdalla et al. (H.E.S.S. Collaboration) A search for dark matter annihilation signals from a new gamma-ray survey of the Galactic Center sets new exclusion limits on the annihilation cross section.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 111101] Published Thu Sep 08, 2022

author.name: H. Abdalla et al. (H.E.S.S. Collaboration)

entry.title: Subrecoil Clock-Transition Laser Cooling Enabling Shallow Optical Lattice Clocks
entry.summary:
Author(s): X. Zhang, K. Beloy, Y. S. Hassan, W. F. McGrew, C.-C. Chen, J. L. Siegel, T. Grogan, and A. D. Ludlow Researchers have cooled ytterbium atoms to a few tens of nanokelvin, which might usher in the next generation of optical atomic clocks.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 113202] Published Thu Sep 08, 2022

author.name: X. Zhang, K. Beloy, Y. S. Hassan, W. F. McGrew, C.-C. Chen, J. L. Siegel, T. Grogan, and A. D. Ludlow

entry.title: Proximity-Induced Gap Opening by Twisted Plumbene in Epitaxial Graphene
entry.summary:
Author(s): Chitran Ghosal, Markus Gruschwitz, Julian Koch, Sibylle Gemming, and Christoph Tegenkamp Intercalation-stabilized plumbene, a lead-based graphene analog, shows a gap at low temperatures that results in a metal-insulator transition.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 116802] Published Thu Sep 08, 2022

author.name: Chitran Ghosal, Markus Gruschwitz, Julian Koch, Sibylle Gemming, and Christoph Tegenkamp

entry.title: Heat Equilibration of Integer and Fractional Quantum Hall Edge Modes in Graphene
entry.summary:
Author(s): G. Le Breton, R. Delagrange, Y. Hong, M. Garg, K. Watanabe, T. Taniguchi, R. Ribeiro-Palau, P. Roulleau, P. Roche, and F. D. Parmentier Neutral modes — chargeless, chiral transport channels that carry energy against the flow of electric current along the edges of the sample — can be coupled to the whole set of charged channels.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 116803] Published Thu Sep 08, 2022

author.name: G. Le Breton, R. Delagrange, Y. Hong, M. Garg, K. Watanabe, T. Taniguchi, R. Ribeiro-Palau, P. Roulleau, P. Roche, and F. D. Parmentier

entry.title: Effect of polymer injection on the development of a trip-wire-induced bypass transitioning boundary layer
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yash Shah and Serhiy Yarusevych Polymer injection in trip-wire induced laminar-to-turbulent transition regions in flat-plate boundary layers is studied experimentally. It is shown that the transition process which is initiated by the amplification of perturbations in a separated shear layer downstream of the trip wire is accelerated by the injection of polymer leading to an earlier breakdown to turbulence. However, significant levels of polymer induced drag reduction are noted in the mid-to-late transitioning regions highlighting a critical shear stress based onset criteria for activation of drag reduction.
[Phys. Rev. Fluids 7, 093901] Published Thu Sep 08, 2022

author.name: Yash Shah and Serhiy Yarusevych

entry.title: Rare-earth monopnictides: Family of antiferromagnets hosting magnetic Fermi arcs
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yevhen Kushnirenko, Benjamin Schrunk, Brinda Kuthanazhi, Lin-Lin Wang, Junyeong Ahn, Evan O'Leary, Andrew Eaton, S. L. Bud'ko, Robert-Jan Slager, P. C. Canfield, and Adam Kaminski The recent discovery of Fermi arcs and new magnetic bands splitting in antiferromagnet NdBi has opened up new avenues for exploration. This study shows that these uncharted effects are not restricted to NdBi, but also emerge in other rare-earth monopnictides. Also, it shows that the relative intensity of the new bands and splitting of these bands scale with the magnetic moments of the rare-earth elements.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 115112] Published Thu Sep 08, 2022

author.name: Yevhen Kushnirenko, Benjamin Schrunk, Brinda Kuthanazhi, Lin-Lin Wang, Junyeong Ahn, Evan O'Leary, Andrew Eaton, S. L. Bud'ko, Robert-Jan Slager, P. C. Canfield, and Adam Kaminski

entry.title: Generation of a Single-Cycle Acoustic Pulse: A Scalable Solution for Transport in Single-Electron Circuits
entry.summary:
Author(s): Junliang Wang, Shunsuke Ota, Hermann Edlbauer, Baptiste Jadot, Pierre-André Mortemousque, Aymeric Richard, Yuma Okazaki, Shuji Nakamura, Arne Ludwig, Andreas D. Wieck, Matias Urdampilleta, Tristan Meunier, Tetsuo Kodera, Nobu-Hisa Kaneko, Shintaro Takada, and Christopher Bäuerle Like a surfer riding a wave, a single electron is transported by an acoustic pulse traveling along the surface of a microchip.
[Phys. Rev. X 12, 031035] Published Wed Sep 07, 2022

author.name: Junliang Wang, Shunsuke Ota, Hermann Edlbauer, Baptiste Jadot, Pierre-André Mortemousque, Aymeric Richard, Yuma Okazaki, Shuji Nakamura, Arne Ludwig, Andreas D. Wieck, Matias Urdampilleta, Tristan Meunier, Tetsuo Kodera, Nobu-Hisa Kaneko, Shintaro Takada, and Christopher Bäuerle

entry.title: Observation of Axisymmetric Standard Magnetorotational Instability in the Laboratory
entry.summary:
Author(s): Yin Wang, Erik P. Gilson, Fatima Ebrahimi, Jeremy Goodman, and Hantao Ji Magnetorotational instability—a process that might explain the dynamics of astrophysical accretion disks—has finally been observed in the laboratory.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 115001] Published Wed Sep 07, 2022

author.name: Yin Wang, Erik P. Gilson, Fatima Ebrahimi, Jeremy Goodman, and Hantao Ji

entry.title: Resonance-Enhanced Vibrational Spectroscopy of Molecules on a Superconductor
entry.summary:
Author(s): Jan Homberg, Alexander Weismann, Troels Markussen, and Richard Berndt Using superconducting materials can increase the strength of scanning-tunneling-spectroscopy signals by up to a factor of 50, allowing the detection of tiny changes in a single molecule’s vibration energy.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 116801] Published Wed Sep 07, 2022

author.name: Jan Homberg, Alexander Weismann, Troels Markussen, and Richard Berndt

entry.title: Higher-order modulations in the skyrmion lattice phase of ${\mathrm{Cu}}_{2}{\mathrm{OSeO}}_{3}$
entry.summary:
Author(s): Johannes D. Reim, Shinnosuke Matsuzaka, Koya Makino, Seno Aji, Ryo Murasaki, Daiki Higashi, Daisuke Okuyama, Yusuke Nambu, Elliot P. Gilbert, Norman Booth, Shinichiro Seki, Yoshinori Tokura, and Taku J Sato Since their first observation, topologically protected swirling spin structures, called skyrmions, have been witnessed in various materials. Here, the authors return to the classic example of Cu2OSeO3 to tackle a remaining issue: external magnetic field dependence of higher-order modulations. Performing long-exposure small-angle-neutron scattering, a clear difference was observed for the field dependence of the (1 1 0) and (2 0 0) modulations. Comparison to numerical Monte Carlo simulations suggest the appearance of weak swirling spin structures depending on the strength of the external magnetic field.
[Phys. Rev. B 106, 104406] Published Wed Sep 07, 2022

author.name: Johannes D. Reim, Shinnosuke Matsuzaka, Koya Makino, Seno Aji, Ryo Murasaki, Daiki Higashi, Daisuke Okuyama, Yusuke Nambu, Elliot P. Gilbert, Norman Booth, Shinichiro Seki, Yoshinori Tokura, and Taku J Sato

entry.title: Measurement of the Low-Temperature Loss Tangent of High-Resistivity Silicon Using a High-$Q$ Superconducting Resonator
entry.summary:
Author(s): M. Checchin, D. Frolov, A. Lunin, A. Grassellino, and A. Romanenko Even though silicon is widely used in superconducting quantum processors as the substrate upon which qubits are fabricated, the effect of silicon on the performance of the qubits is not fully understood. Using ultrahigh-quality microwave cavities to measure dielectric loss with parts-per-billion precision, the authors clearly show that using silicon is detrimental to qubit coherence time. The loss tangent found here is an order of magnitude worse than previously measured. This study sheds light on the physical mechanisms behind dissipation in silicon, and highlights the need for further work to fully understand the origin of these losses, and how to mitigate them.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034013] Published Wed Sep 07, 2022

author.name: M. Checchin, D. Frolov, A. Lunin, A. Grassellino, and A. Romanenko

entry.title: Wavelength-Tunable Quantum Absorption Spectroscopy in the Broadband Midinfrared Region
entry.summary:
Author(s): Masaya Arahata, Yu Mukai, Toshiyuki Tashima, Ryo Okamoto, and Shigeki Takeuchi Infrared quantum absorption spectroscopy (IRQAS) enables the estimation of a sample’s optical properties in the infrared region, using only a visible light source and detectors, which is technologically favorable. So far, spectral coverage of IRQAS systems has been limited to less than 1 µm. This work reports a wavelength-tunable IRQAS system and an efficient measurement scheme to achieve broadband spectroscopy in a short acquisition time. The successful demonstration of rapid spectral measurement over a wide midinfrared window (1.9–5.2 µm) exhibits the great potential of this technique and paves the way for the use of IRQAS in real-world applications.
[Phys. Rev. Applied 18, 034015] Published Wed Sep 07, 2022

author.name: Masaya Arahata, Yu Mukai, Toshiyuki Tashima, Ryo Okamoto, and Shigeki Takeuchi

entry.title: Final Result on the Neutrinoless Double Beta Decay of $^{82}\mathrm{Se}$ with CUPID-0
entry.summary:
Author(s): O. Azzolini et al. The CUPID-0 experiment has demonstrated a new detector technology that targets neutrinoless double beta decay.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 111801] Published Tue Sep 06, 2022

author.name: O. Azzolini et al.

entry.title: Active Nematic Flows over Curved Surfaces
entry.summary:
Author(s): Samuel Bell, Shao-Zhen Lin, Jean-François Rupprecht, and Jacques Prost When epithelial tissue cells move on curved surfaces, they display different patterns from those they form on flat surfaces—according to a new theory.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 118001] Published Tue Sep 06, 2022

author.name: Samuel Bell, Shao-Zhen Lin, Jean-François Rupprecht, and Jacques Prost

entry.title: Decomposing the Local Arrow of Time in Interacting Systems
entry.summary:
Author(s): Christopher W. Lynn, Caroline M. Holmes, William Bialek, and David J. Schwab Researchers have developed a way to quantitatively evaluate irreversibility in complex networks.
[Phys. Rev. Lett. 129, 118101] Published Tue Sep 06, 2022

author.name: Christopher W. Lynn, Caroline M. Holmes, William Bialek, and David J. Schwab

entry.title: Emergence of local irreversibility in complex interacting systems
entry.summary:
Author(s): Christopher W. Lynn, Caroline M. Holmes, William Bialek, and David J. Schwab The authors of this paper investigate irreversibility in a multicomponent system whose components may or may not break detailed balance, and describe a powerful method that can provide insight into the origin of irreversibility in biological systems. This is a must-read paper if you want to understand the details of their technique that “sorts” various sources of irreversibility into contributions from single elements, pairs, triplets, and higher-order interactions.
[Phys. Rev. E 106, 034102] Published Tue Sep 06, 2022

author.name: Christopher W. Lynn, Caroline M. Holmes, William Bialek, and David J. Schwab
